quiz.title: Calculus Limits Quiz 17
quiz.subtitle: Intermediate Value Theorem — Graduate Level Applications (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Calculus

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [0,1] with f(0)=0, f(1)=1. For any countable set S ⊆ (0,1), there exists c ∈ (0,1) such that f(c) ∉ S. This statement is:
options: True only if f is strictly monotonic
True only if S is finite
questions.explanation: The image f([0,1]) is uncountable (connected set), while S is countable, so f([0,1]) cannot be contained in S ∪ {0,1}.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [0,1] satisfies f(0)=0 and has the property that f(x) ∈ ℚ for all x ∈ ℚ. Then f must be:
options: Not necessarily any of the above
questions.explanation: Many non-linear functions preserve rationality on rational inputs (e.g., f(x)=x²). The condition doesn't force linearity.

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [a,b] and let E = {x ∈ [a,b] : f(x) = sup f}. If E is disconnected, then:
options: f must be constant on some subinterval
There exists c where f(c) = inf f between components of E
E must contain at least 3 points
questions.explanation: If E is disconnected, take points from different components. By IVT on the path between them (avoiding E), f takes all values between sup f and some lower value, but wait - f is constant = sup f on E, so between components f must be strictly less than sup f, then by continuity takes intermediate values.

questions.question: A continuous function f on ℝ satisfies f(x+1)=f(x) and f(x+√2)=f(x) for all x. Then f must be:
questions.explanation: The set {m+n√2 : m,n ∈ ℤ} is dense in ℝ. Since f is continuous and constant on a dense set, f must be constant everywhere.

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [0,1] with f(0)=f(1)=0. If for every y ∈ (0,1) the equation f(x)=y has at least 2 solutions, then f must have:
questions.explanation: Since f takes each positive value at least twice and f(0)=f(1)=0, f must go positive in between, hence has a positive maximum. It could stay non-negative.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [0,1] satisfies f(0)=0 and the functional equation f(x+y) = f(x) + f(y) for all x,y with x+y ≤ 1. Using only continuity (not measure theory), prove f(x)=cx. The key step is:
options: Show f(r)=cr for r ∈ ℚ by induction
questions.explanation: For Cauchy functional equations, one first proves f(q)=cq for rational q, then uses continuity to extend to all reals. IVT isn't directly used here.

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [a,b] and let g(x) = sup{t ∈ [a,x] : f(t) = f(x)}. Then g is:
questions.explanation: g(x) is the leftmost point where f takes the value f(x). It's non-decreasing, constant on intervals where f is constant, and continuous by the intermediate value property of f.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [0,1] has the property that f(x) is transcendental for all transcendental x. Then f must be:
options: Not necessarily any of the above
questions.explanation: Many functions preserve transcendence (e.g., f(x)=x²). The condition doesn't determine the function uniquely.

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [0,1] with f(0)=0, f(1)=1. For any ε>0, there exists a polynomial p with |f(x)-p(x)|<ε for all x, and p(0)=0, p(1)=1. This is:
questions.explanation: This is the Weierstrass Approximation Theorem with additional endpoint conditions, which can be achieved by adjusting any approximating polynomial.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [0,1] satisfies f(0)=0 and has the property that for every x, the set {y : f(y)=f(x)} is connected. Then f is:
options: Either strictly monotonic or constant on intervals
questions.explanation: The level sets are connected intervals. This means f is either strictly monotonic (each value taken once) or constant on intervals.

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [a,b] and define F(x)=∫ₐˣ f(t)dt. If F has n zeros in (a,b), then f has at least:
questions.explanation: By Rolle's Theorem applied to F, between consecutive zeros of F there is at least one zero of f' = f. So n zeros of F give at least n-1 zeros of f.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [0,1] satisfies f(0)=0 and f(x) > 0 for x > 0. If lim_{x→0⁺} f(x)/x = 0, then:
questions.explanation: f(x)/x → 0 means f(x) = o(x), but this doesn't guarantee differentiability at 0 (f could oscillate wildly while still being o(x)).

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [0,1] with f(0)=0. The set {x : f(x) = ∫₀ˣ f(t)dt} is:
questions.explanation: Consider g(x)=f(x)-∫₀ˣ f(t)dt. g(0)=0. If g is identically 0, done. Else, g takes both positive and negative values, so by IVT, g(c)=0 for some c>0.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [0,1] has the property that f(x) is constructible for all constructible x. Then f must be:
questions.explanation: Many functions preserve constructibility (e.g., f(x)=x²). The condition is very weak and doesn't determine f.

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [a,b] and let P be a property such that if f has P on two overlapping intervals, then f has P on their union. If f has P on each [x,x+ε] for some ε>0, then f has P on [a,b]. This is:
questions.explanation: This is a standard connectedness argument: the set where f has P is both open and closed in the relative topology, hence is the whole interval.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [0,1] satisfies f(0)=0 and f(1)=1. For any infinite sequence {xₙ} dense in [0,1], there exists a subsequence {xₙₖ} such that f(xₙₖ) converges to 1/2. This is:
options: True only if f is surjective
questions.explanation: Since f is continuous on [0,1], its image contains [0,1]. In particular, there are points where f is near 1/2. By density, we can find such points in the sequence.

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [0,1] with f(0)=0. If for every ε>0, the set {x : |f(x)|<ε} is dense, then:
options: f must have a zero in every interval
questions.explanation: f(x)=x·sin(1/x) for x>0, f(0)=0 is continuous and has points arbitrarily close to 0 in every interval, but is not identically 0.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [0,1] has the property that f(Q) ⊆ Q and f(ℝ\Q) ⊆ ℝ\Q. Then f must be:
options: A linear function with rational coefficients
questions.explanation: Functions that preserve both rationals and irrationals are precisely the linear functions f(x)=ax+b with a,b ∈ Q, a≠0, or constant functions (but constants don't preserve irrationals unless the constant is irrational).

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [0,1] with f(0)=0. The set of points where f is not locally constant is:
questions.explanation: Constant functions are continuous and locally constant everywhere, so the set of points where f is not locally constant can be empty.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [0,1] satisfies f(0)=0 and has the property that for every x, the limit lim_{h→0} (f(x+h)-f(x-h))/h exists. Then f is:
questions.explanation: The symmetric derivative can exist everywhere without the derivative existing (e.g., f(x)=|x| at 0). Continuity plus existence of symmetric derivative doesn't imply differentiability.

scoreMessages.90: Genius level! You've mastered graduate-level IVT and connectedness arguments.
scoreMessages.70: Exceptional! You handle advanced topological and measure-theoretic concepts.
scoreMessages.50: Outstanding! You're comfortable with deep continuity properties.
scoreMessages.0: Review connectedness, density arguments, and functional equations.
